awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Physics of Fundamental and Cosmological Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Marc Kamionkowski and David E. Kaplan at Johns Hopkins University.

The search to understand the fundamental laws of physics is at an exciting but uncertain time. While we eagerly await the discovery of new physics at the LHC or with the next decade of dark-matter searches, existing null results have forced theorists to discard old prejudices and think deeply about entirely new ideas for fundamental physics and novel experimental avenues to seek new physics. Recent developments in observational/experimental cosmology provide the exciting prospect of opening wholly new windows to the very earliest Universe and of understanding the physics driving the accelerated cosmic expansion and the nature of dark matter.  The research of Kamionkowski and Kaplan tackles central problems at the juncture of theory and experiment in particle physics and cosmology.  Their work will advance new ideas for cosmological observations and fundamental-physics searches, and they will propose new mechanisms and models that may ultimately help in the grand synthesis of nature's laws.   This research will proceed hand in hand with the training of students and postdocs who will become scientific leaders in subsequent generations, and the group will remain vigorous in its quest to communicate the excitement of particle physics and cosmology to the general public.  Theoretical research along these lines advances the national interest by optimizing our investment in major experimental facilities in their quest to understand new physical laws.

More technically, Kaplan will develop new non-accelerator directions for exploring the fundamental laws of nature while pushing to pursue a deeper understanding of the phenomena we see. Kamionkowski will develop novel ways to search for new physics with astrophysical observations and non-accelerator experiments. He will study new ideas for dark energy, develop novel techniques to decode cosmic microwave background measurements, and develop theoretical underpinnings to support large-scale-structure probes of inflation and dark energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported research in theoretical physics aimed at understanding the fundamental laws of nature and some of the most significant cosmic mysteries in the Universe.  Although we have a successful mathematical model for the behavior of elementary particles, the model requires several seemingly ad hoc postulates.  Some of the work supported by this grant involved the study of an array of mathematical models, quantum field theories, that provide the basis for our current Standard Model of elementary-particle physics.  We obtained results on quantum field theories with novel symmetries that resemble the Standard Model and some of its ingredients in a number of ways.  We also studied possible solutions to the dark-matter and dark-energy problems and also developed models to explain the origin of the Universe.  Several new hypotheses for the nature of dark matter were developed, as were ideas for novel experiments to test these ideas.  The ideas proposed here are now leading to the development of new experiments that will implement these tests.  One of the biggest mysteries in cosmology today is the "Hubble tension," a disparity between the values of the cosmic expansion rate inferred from observations of the current Universe and from observations of relics from the early Universe.  Work supported by this grant led to the development of the idea of early dark energy, a class of cosmological models that can account for this Hubble tension through the introduction of a new exotic phase of matter that plays a role in the evolution of the early Universe.  The research supported by this grant was pursued in tandem with the training of graduate students and postdocs who will evolve to the next generation of scientific leaders.
